poem:
### Oscar Night

In red velvet rows,  
the unknowns await  
beneath gaudy beams—  
spoken dreams shaping  
pantomime silence.  
  
A flicker of names  
on tongues, rolling like  
dice tossed, no certainty  
but hope, burning bright.  
  
Paper lives unfurl,  
frocks—colored smoke,  
in this night's fragile  
theater of desire.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Fires, frocks and the president who must not be named: my very weird night in the Oscars cheap seats It’s the calm before the storm of the 97th Academy Awards and the announcer, Nick Offerman, is rehearsing his lines on the auditorium’s PA system. He introduces the nominees and trails the potential stories. He says: “Conclave won six awards tonight, including best picture,” and then pauses a moment to allow this momentous result to sink". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Fires, frocks and the president who must not be named: my very weird night in the Oscars cheap seats It’s the calm before the storm of the 97th Academy Awards and the announcer, Nick Offerman, is rehearsing his lines on the auditorium’s PA system. He introduces the nominees and trails the potential stories. He says: “Conclave won six awards tonight, including best picture,” and then pauses a moment to allow this momentous result to sink
